Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description
As the need and demand for technically skilled workforce increases to meet the technical advances of the 21st century life, it is important to attract and sustain the interest of youth, especially those from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). This award from the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) aims to engage pre-college students from under-represented minority groups as well as prospective first-generation college students in an after-school and intensive summer programs and train them in three emerging technologies - unmanned aerial systems (UAS), 3-D printers, and code-able digital devices. The "Teaching through Technologies (T3) Alliance" program will recruit instructors and students from the nationally well-established Upward Bound sites and provide them the needed online and in-person support to adopt a curriculum detailing the scientific background and hands-on use of these three technologies. In addition to the technological instruction, students will also receive instruction in STEM communication and leadership and will participate in a team or individual service project in which their new skills can be used to address and solve an issue of relevance to their local community using the acquired technical knowledge. Over the three years of the project, it is expected that 360 or more underrepresented minority, low-income, and first-generation-to-college students from 36 institutions of higher education in 18 EPSCoR jurisdictions will be engaged in this project.
Technical Description
The vision of this project called, "Teaching through Technologies (T3) Alliance," is to provide a replicable, adaptable, and scalable curriculum and a comprehensive support mechanism that can be widely adopted to increase the STEM interest and engagement of high school students from underrepresented minority groups. The project will focus on three emerging technological areas related to unmanned aerial systems, 3-D printers, and codeable digital devices. Course content, instruction, and robust interactive communication will enable instructors and students to: 1) exchange current activities and ideas across sites; 2) collaborate on problem-solving challenges; 3) discover STEM fields and career paths; 4) access robust instructor training and support; and 5) establish two- way communication with STEM career professionals and societies. The program will be led by Alaska Upward Bound program with close partnership with the Council for Opportunity in Education, Educating4Leadership, and Thrive Design Enterprises in Alaska. The project plans to engage 36 Upward Bound sites in 18 EPSCoR jurisdictions. By engaging the students in hands-on technical learning and enabling them to apply this knowledge in a service project of relevance to their communities, the project will encourage the students to further pursue STEM study and careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "Teaching Through Technologies (T3) Alliance" attracted underrepresented students to STEM fields by used three high-interest technologies ? codable digital devices (Raspberry Pi), 3D printers, and autonomous systems (drones, rovers, and submersibles). Participants in the project demonstrated to themselves that their capacity to learn is not fixed or limited. Students used their new technology knowledge and the Design Thinking process to solve a local community issue.

The Teaching Through Technology (T3) Alliance project has been implemented successfully with a diversified demographic of low-income, first-generation college students from mixed-density rural and urban high schools across all EPSCoR jurisdictions. The T3 Alliance activities are implemented during the school year and intensive summer programs where students have the direct supervision of counselors or instructors in lessons in technology, Growth Mindset, Design Thinking, and Community Engagement.

The T3 Alliance exceeded expectations in the number of program participants, and evaluation success indicators reached 35 Upward Bound programs and more than 1,400 students. Sixteen Upward Bound programs self-support by paying for their participation, demonstrating the replication value and application of the T3 Alliance project.

The T3 Alliance achieved three overarching goals:

1. Increase Upward Bound instructors' and students' knowledge of emerging technologies used in STEM fields.

2. Provide a scalable curriculum with face-to-face and virtual support that increased students? knowledge of STEM career options.

3. Demonstrate teacher and student proficiency by engaging in local community service projects.

Participants were recruited from nationwide Upward Bound and Talent Search programs, which target low-income and first-generation college attending students to prepare them to succeed in college. Many student participants in these after-school and summer instruction programs come from low-resourced schools that may not have advanced classes, tech materials, or teachers that can offer STEM instruction.

The instructional team adapted to the unique circumstances created by the COVID-19 pandemic by continuing to provide training through webinars and creating an online curriculum they could share with students.

The T3 Alliance training, curriculum, and support network has demonstrated it is replicable and scalable in programs across the country. The project engaged programs that ranged geographically - from Puerto Rico, Louisiana, Mississippi, Kansas, Montana, Seattle, Alaska, Hawaii, Guam, and the Marshall Islands ? blending well in urban, rural, and demographically diverse communities.

Additionally, the T3 Alliance curriculum diversified into other STEAM-related topics like Node-RED coding, seismology, weather, remote data acquisition (such as CO2 sensors), plastic recycling, and laser cutting.

Interest to grow and sustain T3 Alliance grew organically. Interest arose beyond the target community to corporate partnerships for student careers and local school interests. To accommodate the demand for training events, a train-the-trainer cadre called Collaborating Coaching Colleagues (C3 trainers) was developed to support the Discord communication channel and provide regional training. The aim is to expand and sustain T3 success by developing strategies to engage local education agencies (LEAs) and interested corporations.
